repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Institutional Reform and
            Capacity Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Institutional Reform and
            Capacity Building Project for Sierra Leone were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            substantial; Bank performance was satisfactory and borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: the rapid enactment of legislation
            regulating the functions and mandates of Local Councils
            (LCs) prevented delays at the implementation stage; in the
            view of the legislative framework, the devolution of
            functions did not need to await the development of adequate
            capacity within the institution of LC. The design of a
            relatively simple and transparent intergovernmental fiscal
            system (first generation grants) set the stage for
            predictable and (in general) timely vertical transfers to
            the LCs. Decentralization is one of the most contested and
            politically difficult reforms to implement in any national
            policy. Trend towards the bi-lateralization of multilateral
            aid calls for rethinking and adjustment of the bank role.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Institutional Reform and
            Capacity Building Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Institutional
            Reform and Capacity Building Project for Sierra Leone is to
            establish a functioning local government system and
            improving the inclusiveness, transparency, and
            accountability of public financial management at all levels
            of government. The Bank team considers the reallocation: (i)
            as a project change within the meaning of (project
            supervision); (ii) does not involve the use of cost of
            project savings, specifically as per footnote 3 to OP 13.25;
            and (iii) does not involve any new change to the original
            project description. Further, the team considers the
            reallocation to be a minor one within the meaning of OP/PB
            13.05. Finally, the reallocation will not result in
            significant changes to the project's description,
            objectives, or associated outcome targets.
